;在安妮·贝克 (Annie Baker) 于 2017 年创作的冷酷讽刺剧《The Antipodes》中，剧作家花了一些时间为电视，向我们展示了她版本的地狱。它看起来很像洛杉矶的作家室，一桌七名男人和一名经常被打断的女人通过转述自己生活中的亲密轶事来产生情节想法。娱乐业对叙事的胃口是无底洞的，随着编剧不断提供私人故事来满足这种胃口，自动蚕食开始出错。外面升起一场圣经风暴，现实裂开，就像贝克戏剧中有时会发生的那样，让不可思议的事情发生。

;

;贝克的最新喜剧，备受期待和大流行延迟的“无限生命，在大西洋，与《Antipodes》完全相反：干旱，2017 年的戏剧被洪水淹没；主角大多是女性，还有一个象征性的单身男性。这也是对她早期恐怖讽刺作品中关于艺术苦难的问题的令人惊讶的真诚甚至热情的回答。在旧金山北部的一家诊所，病人正在禁食，以阻止正在吞噬他们的疾病——癌症、慢性莱姆病。当他们挨饿时，他们的新陈代谢会减慢，对某些人来说，他们的症状会消退。 《对映体》和《无限生命》都是贝克思考苦难的起点，但是，尽管它提到了地狱之火般的痛苦，《无限生命》并不是地狱。没有任何东西可以生长，所以没有东西可以死亡。死亡率处于搁置状态。这家诊所对于病人来说是炼狱，但它也是一种奇异的伊甸园。

;

;并不是说它很茂盛。 “天堂”一词源自波斯语，意思是“有围墙的花园”，在詹姆斯·麦克唐纳的精美作品中，由集体点设计，重点是墙壁。一个摆满躺椅的砖砌露台靠在一条带有风格化花卉图案的混凝土砌块走廊上——让人想起六十年代的汽车旅馆和摩尔式庭院——而露台本身又靠着土坯墙。在《无限生命》的大部分时间里，我们都在看着五位女性在这些躺椅上等待接受治疗。 （人们可能会想起 2016 年卡里尔·丘吉尔 (Caryl Churchill) 执导的后世界末日电影《独自逃亡》(Escaped Alone) 中的一排坐着的女性，这部电影也是由麦克唐纳 (Macdonald) 执导。）她们拿着水瓶、几本书，以及随之而来的奇怪、滑稽的清晰度。几天没吃东西后。他们每个人都有一个看不见的伴侣——痛苦难以形容，他们只能谈论其他事情。

;

;四十七岁的索菲（克里斯蒂娜·柯克，声音中带着抱怨）正在直播。当戏剧开始时，她是禁食的第一天；当戏剧结束时，她将在演出结束后前往机场。由于她的经历是戏剧的时间框架，因此她还负责在时钟向前跳动时通知观众。 “二十分钟后，”索菲一边宣布，一边将目光转向我们。或“七小时后”，伊莎贝拉·伯德 (Isabella Byrd) 设计的灯光从接近黑暗的地方突然变成了炽热的早晨。其他女性都比她年长数十岁：知识渊博的退伍军人伊薇特（米娅·卡提巴克饰）、脆弱的艾琳（玛丽路易斯·伯克饰）、爱讽刺的吉妮（克里斯汀·尼尔森饰）和自信的伊莱恩（布伦达·普雷斯利饰）。

;<在女人们杂乱无章、看似漫无目的的聊天中，主题出现了，包括身体不自觉的推拉（“我们的眼睛里也有微小的括约肌，”吉尼说，这是剧中对括约肌最不明确的提及），失去作为道德指导（索菲正在读乔治·艾略特的《丹尼尔·德隆达》，尽管她还没有到达女主人公成熟的部分），以及解释一种感觉是徒劳的，无论是痛苦、欲望还是恐惧。伊莱恩讲述了一个关于试图阻止丈夫对她大喊大叫的故事。他们选定了一个安全词“chimichanga”，有那么一会儿，她对他的喊叫感到害怕，但是，她告诉大家，“我会说 chimichanga，他会开始尖叫，你们不能说 chimichanga，否则你们知道不值得吃墨西哥卷饼。”

;
;
;

;年长的女性可能已经经历了婚姻风暴，但索菲仍处于婚姻风暴之中。晚上，我们听到她给丈夫留下痛苦的信息（“我想我应该试着告诉你那是什么感觉，而不是仅仅说我很痛苦，我很痛苦，为我感到难过，皮特，我很痛苦”）以及给其他人发送肮脏的信息。我们意识到，她强烈的性欲也在折磨着她。然后诊所里孤独的人尼尔森（皮特·辛普森，做了一个非常有趣的硅谷优化兄弟的模仿），脱掉衬衫漫步到露台上，躺在躺椅上。克里斯汀·尼尔森 (Kristine Nielsen)，我们最精确的舞台喜剧演员之一，在为大家发言时，她的声音颤抖着降低了八度：“我们刚才在说什么？”如果有花园，就一定有诱惑。

;

;贝克是安妮·沃什伯恩和布兰登·雅各布斯-詹金斯等富有冒险精神的作家之一，他们利用表面现实主义来暗示更深层次、更不祥的潮流。 ：该学派认为，世界的大部分地区都是隐藏的。贝克作品的独特之处在于她的对话，她的对话自然而然地徘徊，就好像她无意中听到的一样，还有她的沉默，她说她在作曲时有节奏地数出沉默。学者们就贝克的沉默撰写了论文，试图理解他们如何将她的戏剧转向更大的自然主义（这是对话实际花费的时间）和更大的神秘感（沉默是间隙，间隙是门户，有时奇怪的东西会到来）通过门户）。她还利用沉默来确保她独特的喜剧时机充满活力，并在预期的尴尬和侧眼反应中保持平静。如果表演者说话，通常也是安静的。在贝克的戏剧表演中，观众总是非常安静。如果我们沙沙作响，我们可能会淹没某人。

;

;我记得在观看《对映体》时，我想，当贝克认真起来时，那会很可怕。她冰冷的目光是如此撕裂——如果她打开它怎么办，我不知道，我？她的戏剧《约翰》是存在主义的广阔而令人毛骨悚然的华丽。她凭借慢核杰作《电影》获得了普利策奖，该片在电影院工作的实时乏味中隐藏了道德悲剧。她的作品受到仔细观察，几乎具有宗教纪律，她在塑造舞台时间方面的创新使她成为当今最重要的戏剧作家之一。然而，尽管我很喜欢她的其他戏剧，但她有趣的讽刺总是与锋利的边缘保持安全距离。

;

;然而，“无限生命”是一把没有手柄的刀。贝克说，她是在经历了无法解决的痛苦之后才写下这本书的——“我知道我想写一部戏剧，但我只能在 Word 文档的顶部写下‘PAIN PAIN PAIN’，”她在 ; 中说道。时尚。在这里，她显然不是通过让我们感到身体上的痛苦来传达不可言喻的，而是借给我们她的角色在极度饥饿使他们与身体分离时所经历的怪异悬念。贝克的影响让我们暂时与他们一起漂流。我们感觉时间在不可预知地流逝。她让我们感受到他们紧张的坚忍，这只是远离痛苦的一种感觉。

;

;奇怪的是，我发现这部干眼剧中最难以忍受的时刻出现在中间，当叙事视角短暂地从行动转向元评论。 “那天晚上你听到我尖叫，”艾琳平静地对索菲说。索菲和剧作家之间的界限变得模糊，特别是因为这个角色的造型看起来很像贝克——卷发、穿着袜子和凉鞋。伯克的声音颤抖而无力。 “我说过没有人应该尝试重现这一点。这是最纯粹形式的痛苦。一分钟就是无限。”等等，我想，贝克真的在诊所的某个地方看到过一个女人崩溃了吗？ “我说过永远不要告诉任何人你看到我这个样子，”艾琳然后对索菲说。 “你说：‘好吧。’ ” 贝克是在告诉我们这个场景侵犯了隐私吗？我还是不确定。在《对跖点》之后，我觉得我理解了贝克的信念，即把别人的痛苦写成文字是怪诞的。但是，在这个奇怪的、令人震惊的场景中，我意识到我错了。语言，就像痛苦一样，可能是一个不精确的信使。 ♦

;;本周，《纽约客》将公布长名单2023 年国家图书奖。今天下午请回来查看翻译文学名单。;

;

;今年青年文学长名单上的三部作品都以假期为特色，情节发生了意想不到的转变：在胡达·法赫米 (Huda Fahmy) 的图画小说《胡达·F 关心？》(Huda F Cares?) 中， ” 一位年轻的穆斯林女孩在全家去迪士尼世界的公路旅行中感到不自在；在丹·桑塔特 (Dan Santat) 的图文回忆录《一切皆有第一次》中，一个笨拙的中学生在一次去欧洲的班级旅行中坠入爱河；在贝蒂·唐 (Betty C. Tang) 的图画小说《降落伞小子》中，三名台湾兄弟姐妹在访问加利福尼亚州时一头扎进了美国文化。

;

;2021 年 8 月一个温暖的早晨，一辆黑色道奇大篷车停在 Foxboro 小学在犹他州北盐湖城，伊莎贝拉·蒂奇诺 (Isabella Tichenor) 下了车，对开学第一天感到兴奋。伊莎贝拉（Isabella），绰号伊兹（Izzy），十岁，穿着膝盖处预先破洞的工装裤。她喜欢跳舞和玩四方格。在她母亲布列塔尼那天拍摄的一张照片中，伊兹和她七岁的妹妹艾迪生以及六岁的弟弟杰克森站在一起，他们都在笑。 “这是美好的一天，”布列塔尼告诉我。但是，新学年开始大约一周后，布列塔尼注意到伊兹变得安静了。她询问了伊兹的新老师。 “妈妈，我认为她不喜欢我，”伊兹说。她解释说，老师不会看她，而且她早上也不像其他学生那样向她打招呼。布列塔尼问伊兹是否是班上唯一的黑人学生。 “我想是的，”伊兹说。

;

;布列塔尼也在犹他州长大，那里的黑人人口不到百分之二。一年级时，同学们开始称她为“N字”。她患有抑郁症，有时甚至很难起床。高中毕业后，她倾向于那些能够奖励她数字天赋的工作——出纳工作，然后是会计工作。 Izzy 出生于 2011 年，是一段短暂恋情的产物。她有引人注目的眉毛，额头上有一颗痣。三四岁的时候，她开始在杂货店和其他公共场所无缘无故地无法安慰地尖叫。有时，她会因为焦虑而说不出话来，只能向布列塔尼拍手，试图把话说出来。布列塔尼认为这些迹象表明伊兹患有自闭症。艾迪生和杰克森出生后，布列塔尼搬到了盐湖地区，将孩子们安排在不同的学校，但对同样患有阅读障碍的伊兹的评估始终是一样的：她在数学、阅读和写作方面落后。在 2017 年进行的一项评估中，当时伊兹六岁，她的一年级老师指出她“孤僻”且“抑郁”。

;

;2018 年，布列塔尼嫁给了一位有兴趣帮助她抚养孩子的男人。她的孩子们。他们搬到了北盐湖城，2019 年，布列塔尼让她的孩子们在福克斯伯勒入学；工作人员早期的热情以及他们为帮助伊兹开始特殊教育计划所做的努力让她深受鼓舞。 “我认为这是一所好学校，”布列塔尼告诉我。 “每个人都很好。”但是，几个月后，;新冠肺炎;-19 导致世界瘫痪，布列塔尼失去了工作；最终，一家人拖欠了房租。 2021 年，他们被逐出公寓。他们在俄亥俄州的一位亲戚那里住了几个月，然后回到盐湖地区，开始在空荡荡的停车场的货车里睡觉，并用毯子盖住窗户。 “这真是一种耻辱，”布列塔尼告诉我。

;

;那年八月，福克斯伯勒终于重新开放全日制面对面学习。布列塔尼带着孩子们去一家二手服装店，在那里他们挑选衣服，她在开学前一天晚上花了一大笔钱订了一家酒店，以便孩子们可以洗澡。但最初的几周很困难。伊兹抱怨她的老师后不久，她和艾迪生告诉母亲，另一名学生声称拥有枪，并威胁要用它向他们开枪。布列塔尼愤怒地给学校打电话。几天后，管理人员告诉她，他们查看了监控录像并搜查了学生的背包，但无法证实这一指控；不会有任何影响。 （负责监管福克斯伯勒的戴维斯学区拒绝对伊兹案件的细节发表评论。）“你能想象如果我的孩子带了枪吗？”布列塔尼问我。 “我的黑人孩子？”

;枪支指控十天后，艾迪生告诉她的母亲，同一个同学触摸了她，并称她为“N”字。布列塔尼立即给学校打电话。第二天早上，她收到了校长的一封电子邮件，校长写道，她和她的工作人员查看了录像，没有看到同学触摸艾迪生。她说，两名目击者声称他们没有听到艾迪生和学生交谈。但校长告诉布列塔尼，她已经想出了一个解决方案：蒂奇诺的孩子和另一个学生可以通过一系列错综复杂的弯路，在学校期间避免彼此。 “这应该可以确保他们在任何时候都不会见面，”校长在电子邮件中写道，“如果他们每个人都按照要求去做的话。” “这已经失控了，”布列塔尼回复道。 “所以基本上，孩子们可以称呼其他孩子 [N 字]！”

;如果 2020 年是 ;乔治·弗洛伊德;和;自此之后的几年里，“黑人生命也是命”运动的特点是遭到强烈反对。其中大部分集中在学校。保守派政客瞄准了; 在内的作家的作品托尼·莫里森;和玛雅·安吉卢，来自学校图书馆和课程。

;

;这些争斗已经延伸到校内骚扰。 2021 年 10 月至 2022 年 9 月期间，教育部民权办公室收到了 899 起学校种族欺凌指控，是前一年指控数量的两倍。在密歇根州的一所高中，浴室里写着种族绰号和死亡威胁——其中有人写道，“杀掉所有[N字]”——学校操场上的绞索上挂着一个黑色娃娃。在明尼苏达州，白人学生在社交媒体上发布了一段视频，怂恿一名黑人学生自杀。 “你他妈的会在地狱里腐烂。 。 。没有人喜欢[N-word]，”一个人对着镜头说道。 “这次就他妈的自杀吧。”正式指控的增加可能部分是由于人们对一直存在的一种骚扰的认识提高以及一种新的表达方式的结果。但波士顿医学中心的儿童和青少年精神病学家克里斯汀·克劳福德认为，政治上的强烈反对也影响了儿童之间的互动。 “他们可能认为这样谈论其他群体是可以的，”她说。 “‘爸爸正在做这件事。我妈妈正在做。有什么问题？'这些互动反过来又成为文化战争的爆发点。当密歇根学校一名黑人学生的家长宣布对学区提起诉讼时，这一消息引发了网上的愤怒。 “我厌倦了世界上超级清醒、最聪明、最自由的黑人，他们表现得就像经历过奴隶制一样，”一位评论者写道。 “你生而自由！现在你的借口是什么。”另一位补充道，“这太假了。”

;福克斯伯勒小学位于盐湖城北部的戴维斯县。该县 61% 的人投票支持;唐纳德·特朗普; 在 2020 年选举中。前院悬挂着“Let's Go Brandon”标语和“Blue Lives Matter”旗帜。 2021 年 2 月，戴维斯学区的一所小学庆祝黑人历史月，在走廊展示了有关黑人历史 ABC 的内容（“P”代表“抗议”；“U”代表“提升”）。犹他州教育委员会的右翼成员娜塔莉·克莱恩 (Natalie Cline) 认为，它宣扬的是“一种极具争议性的意识形态”，因此装饰被拆除。几个月后，该学区禁止展示所有“黑人生命也是命”旗帜以及 LGBTQ 骄傲旗帜，称它们政治色彩太浓。 “除了美利坚合众国的国旗外，我们的学校里没有任何旗帜飘扬，”学区发言人告诉当地媒体。

;
;
;

;该地区的黑人学生长期以来一直是种族欺凌的目标。 2022 年从该地区一所高中毕业的布林·马丁代尔 (Brynn Martindale) 告诉我，在学前班时，另一个孩子说：“我爸爸不喜欢黑人，所以我也不喜欢黑人。”中学时，一位白人同学开始称马丁代尔为“胖黑人”。她的头发被“老师、学生、教会领袖、随机的成年人，每个人”碰过。艾莉森·施利希特（Allison Schlichter）是一位从埃塞俄比亚收养黑人女儿的白人家长，她告诉我，一名一年级的学生告诉她的女儿，她的头发和肤色“很愚蠢”。当施利希特提出投诉后，校长驳回了此事，称学生所说的话相当于告诉别人他们的衣服不时髦。 “我完全惊慌失措，”施利希特告诉我。 “我不能再把女儿送回那里了。”她让女儿退学，到另一个学区就读一年。另一位黑人孩子的白人家长肖特尔·布莱克 (Shauntel Black) 告诉我，当白人学生在小学操场上推搡她的儿子贾斯图斯时，他为自己辩护，他受到了惩罚，而攻击他的人却没有受到惩罚。 “每年他都被告知他的皮肤看起来像便便，”布莱克说。

;

;2018 年左右，施利希特和另一位家长艾米丽·弗斯 (Emily Furse) 开始收集其他父母的故事，最终积累了数百页的故事。第二年，;视频片段;照片中，一名来自该地区的白人公交车司机将公交车门夹在一名混血学生的背包上，并将他拖了一百五十多英尺。该事件成为全国新闻。 Schlichter 和 Furse 的故事集随后送达司法部。

;2019 年 6 月，两名司法部律师前往犹他州调查该学区是否违反了《宪法》第四章民权法案，禁止基于种族的歧视。黑人学生告诉律师，他们的白人同学经常称他们为“N”字，或者称他们为“猴子”或“猿”，并发出猴子的声音。白人学生未经允许触摸、拉扯黑人学生的头发，并让他们摘棉花。有些人展示或佩戴邦联旗帜。有些人经常要求黑人学生提供“N 字通行证”，他们坚称这允许他们使用 N 字而不会产生任何后果；当拒绝这一请求时，白人学生有时会威胁或殴打黑人同学。他们称黑人学生的皮肤脏，或者说看起来像粪便，质问他们为什么不洗。管理人员知道，在短短三年内，至少有 212 起黑人学生被称为 N 字的事件记录在案。司法部律师发现，使用诽谤性言论的学生很少受到纪律处分。一些承认听到这些绰号的老师表示，他们只是告诉违法者“注意他们的语言”；工作人员对煽动者的行为进行了解释，称他们“并不是想成为种族主义者。”

;

;在接受司法部一名律师（黑人、白人助理校长）的采访时，反复引用了一段对话使用了N字，没有经过审查。在另一次采访中，一名白人工作人员表示，学生和律师一样都是“有色人种”。 “我认为我们所有人，团队中的每个人都感到震惊和震惊，”一位参与调查的律师告诉我。 “真的很难听到这些学生的经历，而且他们普遍感到孤立，除此之外，几乎没有人可以交谈和求助。这真是令人心碎。”

;到晚了2021 年 9 月，伊兹和她的家人已经无家可归至少三个月了。布列塔尼每天下午都会去福克斯伯勒接孩子们，然后开车去卡车站或城市公园过夜。早上，他们会在休息站或快餐店找到一个卫生间，清理干净，穿好衣服去上学。布列塔尼在很远的地方从事出纳工作，使用的是她用食品券购买的汽油。有时，她会凑够钱请家人在酒店住一晚，他们会开空调并叫客房服务。艾迪生和杰克森似乎适应了这种情况，把它当作一次露营旅行，但伊兹很难适应。在课堂上，伊兹的老师似乎很难与她建立联系。老师在评价中写道，“她似乎没有太多情绪，我不知道是因为她不明白发生了什么，还是不在乎。” （戴维斯学区拒绝让福克斯伯勒工作人员对这篇文章发表评论。伊兹的老师没有回应评论请求。）那年秋天，布列塔尼第二次要求进行评估，以正式诊断她的女儿患有自闭症。 （布列塔尼没有完成之前尝试的所有步骤。）她希望，如果学校承认伊兹的残疾，伊兹就能得到她需要的治疗。

;

;有一天，布列塔尼发现伊兹在洗澡。与纺必适一起。当她妈妈问为什么时，伊兹告诉她学校里的孩子们说她闻起来很难闻。在她的老师向全班同学讲述淋浴和泡澡的重要性后，嘲笑变得更加严重。伊兹觉得这场讲座是针对她的。布列塔尼打电话抱怨，要求老师以后和她讨论女儿的卫生问题，而不是在其他学生面前讨论。老师解释说，个人卫生只是她经常与班级讨论的事情，根据布列塔尼的回忆，老师要求她冷静下来。 “我说，‘你别告诉我要冷静’，因为白人总是这么说。”布列塔尼告诉我。

;

;那年秋天晚些时候，布列塔尼找到了一份更稳定的工作，薪水一美元。店铺。她和她的丈夫凑了钱和一些住房券，并支付了一套公寓的首付——一套三层两居室的联排别墅风格的空间，有自己的车库、花岗岩台面和全新的电器。 。当布列塔尼十月份带孩子们去那里时，他们欣喜若狂。 “现在我们可以做饭了！”伊兹一边说，一边把手抚过柜台。该公寓位于戴维斯区之外，布列塔尼希望让她的孩子进入一所新学校。

;

;与此同时，在福克斯伯勒，欺凌行为变得更加严重。伊兹说，学生们把注意力集中在她的浓眉上，眉毛已经开始长成一字眉，还有额头上的“点”。她恳求妈妈：“我需要你帮我剪眉毛。人们都在取笑我。”布列塔尼试图安慰她。 “你很漂亮，”她说。 11 月 2 日星期二，布列塔尼让女儿逃学，搬进新房子，让她远离那些折磨她的人。那天晚上，又一个上学日临近，伊兹变得沮丧，把自己关在母亲的卧室里。 “她只是躺在我房间衣柜前的地上，”布列塔尼告诉我。布列塔尼下楼打开行李，但提醒伊兹她第二天要完成一张读书报告海报，为此他们买了新的彩色铅笔。 “当我回到楼上时，我们就会这么做，”她说。 “你兴奋吗？”伊兹微微一笑。

;

;在车库里，布列塔尼和她的丈夫翻箱倒柜地把照片挂在房子周围。几分钟后，艾迪生和杰克森闯入，说伊兹试图自杀。他们都跑到顶楼，找到了伊兹。布列塔尼的丈夫拨打了 911 并进行了心肺复苏。伊兹被紧急送往医院。当布列塔尼走进病房时，伊兹嘴里插着管子，眼里流着泪水。布列塔尼最初认为这是一个积极的信号，但工作人员解释说，这很可能是无意识反射的结果。到那个星期五，伊兹已经昏迷了三天。医生告诉布列塔尼，伊兹的病情可能永远不会好转。第二天下午，她停止了生命支持。 11月6日，她被宣布死亡。 “我的一部分已经死了，”布列塔尼说。

;Izzy 的自杀使本已分裂的学区陷入危机。美国司法部刚刚公布了调查结果，发现该学区“以明显不合理的方式应对广泛、普遍的基于种族的骚扰……”，损害了有色人种学生的权利。 。 。受到学​​生和教职员工的欢迎。”在一封描述其调查结果的信中，司法部报告了普遍使用黑字、种族嘲讽和人身威胁的情况。该学区还对“黑人学生进行了比有类似行为的白人学生更严厉、更频繁的纪律处分。”在一个案件中，一名黑人学生受到刑事指控。美国司法部民权部门负责人克里斯汀·克拉克 (Kristen Clarke) 告诉我，调查结果“有力地提醒我们，我们不能忽视仇恨的表现方式……” 。 。包括我们学校内部。”该学区同意达成和解，其中包括对教师和管理人员进行如何识别和报告种族骚扰的培训，以及建立一个供家庭、学生和教师登记投诉的电子报告系统。报告发布后任命的戴维斯市警长丹·林福德 (Dan Linford) 告诉我，他对所揭露的种族骚扰的严重性感到惊讶，并表示调查结果中描述的行为令人遗憾。他说：“我们不能逃避解决这个问题的责任。”

;

;在社区中，司法部的调查结果存在分歧。许多黑人当地人对这份报告表示欢迎。刚从该地区一所高中毕业的马丁代尔告诉我，当权者听到了她的声音，她感到松了一口气。但她的一些朋友并不买账。 “我的白人朋友说，‘不，这不会发生。那不是一件事。林福德指出，“最初的反应是很多人完全否认这一点。”施利希特是收集有关黑人学生所受待遇的故事的家长之一，她告诉我，因为她直言不讳地谈论种族骚扰，“我实际上失去了一半的朋友和家人。”那年 11 月，在戴维斯学校董事会会议上，一名居民表达了对和解协议的愤怒，他说：“你只是……” 。 。邀请联邦政府进入我们的学校，监督我们的孩子和老师。”一位头戴印有“让美国伟大”字样的红色棒球帽、身穿犹他爱国者队 T 恤的演讲者走上讲台说道：“我认为这只不过是一次大力推动 CRT、跨性别者、同性恋——整个运动——从我们的视野中走下来”。喉咙。”

;当然，很难知道是什么原因导致自杀。儿童精神病学家克劳福德告诉我，幸存的亲人往往会出于特定的动机，但事情很少那么简单。 “每个人都有自己这样做的理由，很难预测谁会真正做出尝试，”她说。有色人种儿童的自杀行为更是鲜为人知。 《美国医学会儿科杂志》2018 年发表的一项;研究;发现，在全国范围内，各个年龄段的黑人儿童五岁和十二岁儿童自杀的可能性是白人儿童的两倍。但我们不了解特定形式的歧视在;那个结果;。加州大学洛杉矶分校的儿童精神病学家埃拉卡·巴斯 (Eraka Bath) 告诉我，当谈到社会行为研究时，“我们有一个科学问题，我们百分之九十的研究都是基于人”——西方的、受过教育的、富有的——他们只代表人口的一小部分。伊兹的处境在很多方面都很困难。她很穷，几个月来无家可归。她的学习障碍使她的学业变得很困难。她的母亲有抑郁症发作史，Izzy 的至少一位老师也观察到她有抑郁症的迹象。

;但布列塔尼 (Brittany) 开始相信，伊兹 (Izzy) 的自杀主要是因为受到欺凌，并且她因种族和残疾而成为攻击目标。伊兹去世后的第二天，一些朋友让布列塔尼与“黑人生命也是命”犹他州分会取得联系，该分会愿意为她处理新闻通讯。 “这是一个十岁的女孩，”该组织的主席雷·达克沃斯 (Rae Duckworth) 告诉我。 “这是一个巨大的损失。”第二天，布列塔尼坐在电视摄像机前，达克沃斯站在她身后，讲述了伊兹在福克斯伯勒受到骚扰的故事。第二天晚上，近两百人聚集在一起举行烛光守夜活动。在犹他爵士队比赛开始前，播音员要求为“伊莎贝拉·费思·蒂奇诺，一个输得太早的孩子”默哀片刻。爵士队向为布列塔尼及其家人设立的 GoFundMe 账户捐赠了五万美元。犹他州临床心理学家、种族压力和创伤研究员金伯利·阿普怀特 (Kimberly Applewhite) 告诉我，“伊兹从学生、教师和管理人员那里收到的模糊、不具体、但仍然相当有针对性和痛苦的反馈，是教科书上的种族主义”。 “每当黑人被剥夺人性时，我们就需要假设正在发生种族主义事件。”

;

;作为回应，该学区委托对伊兹因她的行为而受到欺凌的指控进行独立调查。种族或残疾。调查由当地律师和另外两名小组成员进行，发现伊兹的妹妹艾迪生很可能是“种族欺凌的目标”。但小组成员表示，他们找不到确凿的证据证明伊兹的欺凌行为是出于种族动机。他们报告说：“当一名学生告诉伊兹她需要洗头时，这种评论可能是出于种族敌意，也可能是无伤大雅的观察，也可能是对贫困的隐晦侮辱。”当我与戴维斯学区的助理学监约翰·祖布琴 (John Zurbuchen) 交谈时，他没有透露案件的细节，但他表示，他相信司法部调查结果中概述的种族欺凌行为与伊兹的自杀无关。 “伊兹之死的悲剧以及我们与司法部合作的时机是不幸的，因为它混淆了这两个问题，”他说。 “除了结果和时间之外，这两件事没有任何关联。”

;

;无论如何，该事件加剧了关于如何处理学校种族问题的争论。认为司法部报告是假新闻的犹他州人接受了对伊兹之死的内部调查，认为这是种族主义被夸大的证据。一位评论者写道：“所以她妈妈在没有证据的情况下大声疾呼种族主义和欺凌行为，而人们只是接受了？？令人震惊。”游说取消黑人历史月展览的州教育委员会成员娜塔莉·克莱恩 (Natalie Cline) 看到了一个阴谋。她在网上发帖称：“学校积极分子利用伊兹自杀的悲剧性死亡事件，将司法部带入戴维斯学区，他们现在将 CRT 政策、计划和课程强加给学生。” “所有这一切都是为了让白人、异性恋、基督徒学生为他们没有做过的事情感到内疚。”

;

;桑德拉·霍林斯 (Sandra Hollins) 是犹他州立法机构中唯一的黑人议员，他发起了《伊兹法案》(Izzy’s Bill)，该法案在全州范围内采用了一些戴维斯与司法部达成的和解协议中出现的措施，包括对学校工作人员进行新的培训，以帮助消除歧视和骚扰。该法案还提议跟踪欺凌受害者的人口统计信息，以确定学生是否因其种族而成为攻击目标。反对派认为这种追踪是对隐私的侵犯，据霍林斯称，反对派坚称“种族不应该成为这一切的一个因素”。该法案最终获得通过，但霍林斯不得不删除所有提及“种族”一词的内容，只保留一处。拥有五万名成员的犹他州家长联合会敦促其追随者公开反对这项法律：“对伊莎贝拉·蒂奇诺的自杀事件进行了广泛的调查，”该组织在社交媒体上向追随者解释道，“结果文件指出”没有直接证据支持伊兹因种族和/或残疾而受到欺凌的说法。 2022 年 11 月，布列塔尼的律师宣布对该学区提起诉讼。她的一位律师是米尔顿·格莱姆斯 (Milton Grimes)，他在罗德尼·金 (Rodney King) 案后代表他。 1991年，遭到洛杉矶警察局的殴打。 “黑人生命也是命”犹他州分会宣布再次举行守夜活动，纪念伊兹去世一周年。作为回应，它收到了匿名威胁，其中使用了 N 字词，称组织者“肮脏”，并说他们的时间到了。消息中写道：“你永远不会看到它的到来。”

;The cemetery where Izzy is buried sits in an affluent Salt Lake suburb. One afternoon last summer, I joined Brittany, Addison, and Jaxson on a visit to Izzy's grave. Some of Izzy's GoFundMe paid for the burial plot, casket, and funeral expenses, but cash ran out before the family could purchase a headstone. When we arrived, Addison and Jaxson burst from the car and ran toward the spot where they thought their older sister rested. They came upon a temporary plastic marker, but it wasn't Izzy's. Soon all three Tichenors were on their hands and knees, running their fingers through the grass, groping for Izzy's name. Finally, Brittany called out, “It's here!,” and the children came running.

;

;The investigations into racial harassment didn't stop with the Davis School District. The US Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights lists pending cases of racial harassment in seven school districts in Utah. There are hundreds more around the nation. Last year, the Education Department reached a settlement with a district in Victorville, California, where school officials disciplined Black students more harshly than white students. And the DOJ reached a settlement with a Kentucky district where students used racial taunts and Confederate flags as intimidation. The Davis School District has been implementing the DOJ's recommendations, but some parents continue to fight them, and at least one withdrew her children from Davis as a result. This past June, Brittany's lawsuit against the district ended in a settlement. The district agreed to give her two million dollars and promised to erect an eighteen-inch statue of Izzy in the Foxboro Elementary library, and a plaque at district headquarters, commemorating her.

;

;Back in the cemetery, Brittany sat cross-legged, her index finger over her daughter's grave marker. Jaxson and Addison placed their fingers over their sister's name, too, then ran off toward a patch of tree shade to make use of some art supplies. Brittany told me that grief had thrown her family into turmoil; she and her husband were in the middle of divorce proceedings. The media spotlight was also taking a toll. People expected her to be a model for how to mourn a dead child, but she didn't always deal with her despair well. She told me that she consumes alcohol more than she should. “I do drink . 。 。 to numb it,” she said. (She later said that she intended to enter rehab.) She told me that, the last night at home, before Izzy killed herself, she had broken out of her despondency to tell Brittany, “You're the best mom in the whole wide world.” Brittany believes that this was Izzy's way of saying goodbye. “Sometimes people say, 'Oh, I'm doing great,' or, 'Yeah, I'm taking it one day at a time.'我不是。 I'm miserable. I miss my child.”

;

;It was getting late. Before they left, Jaxson came running over to show his mother what he had been working on. He handed her a sheet of white paper covered in crayon lines. It was a map, he said, so that next time they could find Izzy. ♦

;During the Maidan uprising, which began in 2013, when Ukrainian protests led to the overthrow of the Kremlin-backed President, Viktor Yanukovych, many of the country's filmmakers banded together to form a collective known as #Babylon'13, focussed on exposing Russian aggression in their country. After Putin launched a ;full-scale invasion;, I began to correspond with some of those filmmakers, hoping to find a local perspective on the war. In March of 2022, I met Dmytro Sukholytkyy-Sobchuk, one of the country's most exciting young auteurs, in a glitchy Zoom meeting. He was signing on from western Ukraine, where he was volunteering with #Babylon'13 to capture the events of the unfolding war. He told me about a group of religious sculptors he had met near Lviv who had been retrained to build defense barriers. We both felt that they would be fascinating subjects for a documentary. That idea became “Liturgy of Anti-Tank Obstacles,” an original film from ;The New Yorker;.

;

;From the start, Dmytro and I both knew that we wanted to make a war film without showing violence. The hope, instead, was to highlight the new reality of everyday Ukranians. Dmytro shot the documentary over three weeks, capturing the artists near Lviv in a transformative moment, one that resonates in the experiences of others throughout the country, as their lives are reshaped by the war and the national-defense effort. The resulting film has premièred at festivals, including Sundance and the Toronto International Film Festival (Dmytro was not able to get a visa to attend), and won first prize in the documentary contest at the Huesca International Film Festival, qualifying it for the 2024 Academy Awards. We recently spoke by Zoom about the making of “Liturgy of Anti-Tank Obstacles,” with Dmytro joining from his Kyiv apartment. The call came during a busy stretch for him; he's teaching filmmaking classes and touring with his début narrative feature, “Pamfir”—which centers on a man involved in criminal enterprises and is set against the backdrop of his village's annual carnival—all while the war grinds on.

;
;
;

;

;Though there is plenty of Eastern Orthodox religious imagery in the film, Dmytro himself is not a believer. (He told me there are three things in life that he considers purely personal: “Who you want to love; who you want to believe in; and what you want to eat. It's your private business.”) Ukraine is a secular country, and President ;Zelensky; is Jewish. What drew him to these artists was not their religiosity but their undertaking of a version of the same pragmatic pivot that he saw throughout the country. As the invasion began, the sculptors were making statues of the Virgin Mary or angels with beatific expressions. Just weeks later, they were building anti-tank obstacles. All over the country, Ukrainians were pivoting to the defense effort. “Whatever you were doing before the war, you start to find your capabilities,” Dmytro told me. “This change impressed me.”

;
;
;

;Dmytro had undergone a similar transformation himself. When the Russian forces invaded, he was in Kyiv with his wife. They live not far from the airport, and he remembers waking up from the bombing; a house nearby was damaged. Right away, he began shooting footage in the capital. He saw his responsibilities as a director overlapping with his responsibilities as a citizen, making films so that “you can see how people defend sovereignty, democracy, territory, and their own lives,” he told me.

;

;For “Liturgy of Anti-Tank Obstacles,” Dmytro took a patient, observational approach to storytelling. The film shows the artists at work, but it doesn't present their individual backstories or personalities. He doesn't mention that two of the three artists are now serving as soldiers in the war. When I asked him about the choice, he said he approached the film this way because of a pattern he had seen during the war: “Everybody in Ukraine, no matter where, they start to be like one person. Not a person. One piece. If you describe somebody's personality, they are unique, like fingerprints. But, if they unite together, they start to be a fist.” His idea was to show in the film the sense of unanimity and collectivism that he saw at work all around him: “They can be a huge fist who can knock out everybody who attacks them.”

;

;Dmytro told me about a recent trip to Paris, where he'd travelled to finish his feature film, which showed how pervasive the reality of the invasion is for people in Ukraine. It was eleven o'clock one night, and he realized that he'd forgotten to buy water. He remembers thinking, Oh, damn, I forgot to buy the water, and I need to wait for the next day. His friends were confused, and reminded him that shops were open late. Oh, damn, he thought again: You don't have a curfew. That simple moment is a reminder of why it's so important for him to tell a story from his own perspective. No matter how empathetic an outsider may be, Dmytro told me, at the end of the day, “They go back to their reality. We go back to our reality.” ♦

;Complex abstractions are hard to convey in movies, but “Dumb Money,” Craig Gillespie's new drama based on the true story of the buying frenzy for ;GameStop stock; and the havoc it created in the finance world, does an unusually good job of it. Gillespie peppers the dialogue with a handful of key terms—“selling short,” “short squeeze,” “margin account”—which the movie both depicts in action and invites viewers to research for themselves. He also neatly organizes the story into three distinct zones, which parse the abstractions all the more clearly: the small-time purchasers of shares in the video-game retailer GameStop, the Wall Street big shots whose wisdom the small-timers defy and whose businesses they threaten, and the lone individual who sparked the showdown: Keith Gill (Paul Dano). Gill was a social-media influencer who, under the pseudonym Roaring Kitty, advocated for the stock on his YouTube videocast. (He delivered the same message on Reddit under the pseudonym DeepFuckingValue.) At the time, he was working in an unglamorous backwater of financial services, as a broker at MassMutual, and he had an axe to grind with Wall Street. As the film's protagonist, Keith is the source of both its main strengths and its weaknesses: his exploits and passions give “Dumb Money” an appealing energy, even as his temperament and mind-set go largely unexamined.

;

;The reason that the buying frenzy Keith had engendered caused trouble was that a number of institutional investors were selling GameStop short. Short selling is a way of betting that a stock price will fall: instead of buying shares in anticipation of eventually selling at a higher price, a short seller borrows stock and immediately sells it, contracting to buy it back at a later date; so long as the stock falls, this yields a profit. In “Dumb Money,” the short sellers are represented by perhaps the biggest and most brazen of them, Gabe Plotkin (Seth Rogen), the founder of a New York-based hedge fund called Melvin Capital. When the story starts, GameStop is trading at $3.85 per share; Gabe believes that it will go even lower, but then Keith begins his pushback to drive the price back up.

;

;Gillespie contrasts Gabe's charmed life—during the pandemic, he decamped to Florida and bought two houses next door to each other, planning to demolish one and build a tennis court on the plot—with Keith's more modest circumstances. The son of a nurse (Kate Burton) and a truck driver (Clancy Brown), Keith grew up in Brockton, Massachusetts, and was the first in his family to graduate from college, a local one. He lives in an unremarkable house with his wife, Caroline (Shailene Woodley), and their infant daughter. After the markets close each day, he retreats to the family basement to produce his Roaring Kitty videos. In them, he displays his balance sheet and discusses, with a snarky and colloquial fervor, his assessment of GameStop and why he thinks that the big firms—despite the mighty resources that he knows they have at their disposal—are getting it wrong. (His main reason: the kind of people who work on Wall Street don't get gaming and gamers.) Keith is as much an entertainer as he is an expert, but he puts his money where his mouth is: he invests heavily in GameStop, and, once his followers buy in, too, the share price skyrockets.

;

;For a short seller like Gabe, this is a big problem. The worst that can happen with an ordinary stock purchase is that the price goes to zero and the investor loses her entire stake. But, as a TV-news commentator explains during the film, there's no limit to how high a stock can go, which means that a short seller's losses are potentially infinite. To avert disaster, short sellers who have made a bad bet may rush to buy back the borrowed stock when it rises. But this creates a further problem: these forced purchases increase demand, thus driving the price even higher and putting all remaining short sellers in an even deeper hole. This is what's known as a short squeeze, and Gabe's company is caught in a terrible one. At one point, he's losing a billion dollars a day and has to run hat in hand to even bigger shots—notably, a pair of hedge-fund CEOs, Steve Cohen (Vincent D'Onofrio), the current owner of the Mets, and Ken Griffin (Nick Offerman). Keith is eating this up, of course.

;

;Meanwhile, who are the regular investors buying GameStop? The movie, written by Lauren Schuker Blum and Rebecca Angelo (based on a ;nonfiction book; by Ben Mezrich), presents a few: a nurse named Jenny (America Ferrera), a GameStop sales clerk named Marcus (Anthony Ramos), and two University of Texas undergraduates, Riri (Myha'la Herrold) and Harmony (Talia Ryder). The students are deep in debt, the nurse and the clerk are struggling to make ends meet, and when they, like many others, follow Keith into investing in GameStop they suddenly make lots of money, hundreds of thousands of dollars—at least on paper. That is to say, they can realize this profit only by selling their shares. And yet they don't sell. This is by far the most interesting and mysterious aspect of the whole story, but it's a mystery that neither Gillespie nor his screenwriters come close to illuminating.

;
;
;

;Keith isn't selling his stock, either: being able to put the squeeze on Gabe and other Wall Street potentates is seemingly worth far more to him than a big payday. He encourages his followers, over whom he has an almost guru-like power, to see their collective buying frenzy as a sort of protest movement. The “smart money” of Wall Street regards small retail investors with derision—that's where the movie's title comes from—but now finds itself at their mercy. (Keith's followers gleefully burlesque their presumed unsophistication, brandishing misspelled signs reading “HODL THE LINE”—ie, don't sell.) By holding, they keep the price up, and even hope that others will join in and send it higher. (One of the students likens the run-up in the stock's price to a Ponzi scheme.) The four depicted investors risk not cashing out in time, and seeing their paper gains vanish when the stock plummets, all because of the “hodl” that Keith has over them. Yet the nature of this cultlike fervor remains utterly unexplored. The fact that Keith does eventually cash out, realizing a profit—unlike some of his followers, who waited too long—is relegated to a concluding title card.

;

;The movie wastes time on setting up a few minor points of the followers' personalities (the nurse wants a man in her life, the students are in a romantic relationship, the clerk is tired of his fussy boss) rather than probing the psychology of a mass movement with strong political overtones. What political points the movie does make are predictable and safe. The oblivious privilege of Wall Street is emphasized throughout, as in the way that Gabe, preparing to give testimony to Congress via Zoom, fails to grasp why appearing in front of his wine collection is a bad look. There's a passing mention, too, of the loosely linked collective's affinities with Occupy Wall Street, but it comes and goes in the blink of its utterance. (There's not even a hint that the anti-élite impulse could serve a Trumpist agenda just as readily as a leftist one.) The screenwriters are notably choosy about which acolytes they choose to dramatize; the presence of antisemitic comments on the group's subreddit briefly becomes a significant plot point, but the antisemites themselves are neither seen nor heard, and the topic is quickly dropped.

;

;Above all, Keith is presented merely as a bundle of idiosyncrasies and remains a cipher. He's an obsessive runner who, when the going gets tough, heads to the track. He's contemptuous of institutions but dismayed, even shocked, when his employers threaten to fire him for his extracurricular financial-world activities. He displays an overt frugality in his personal habits but has a lavishly equipped basement studio. Dano's performance, abounding in nervous energy and revelling in puckish mannerisms, suggests a depth that's absent from anything in the script. How Keith got started, how he built a following, what drives him to center his identity on his videos and posts are all left blank. His laconic self-justification (“I like the stock”) is tantalizingly inscrutable: behind it surely lurks a perspective that amounts almost to an aesthetics of investing, but the movie is unwilling or unable to delve further.

;

;Still, the mechanisms that “Dumb Money” ably exposes retain a cold, clinical fascination. If it doesn't come close to the achievement of “;The Wolf of Wall Street;”—whose intoxicating depiction of the will to power included profiteers getting their marks to share in the thrill—it nonetheless has an urgency that “;The Big Short;,” mired in the pride of its outrage and the vanity of its antics, never achieves. “Dumb Money,” touching on questions of the authority of personality and the importance of nonfinancial—even completely irrational—motives in the investment world, offers a gleeful romp through strange and treacherous territory that merits a closer, more careful look. ♦

;Last month, ;Billboard; published a gloomy survey of record-label executive sentiment about the state of the music industry. Many of those interviewed lamented one unsettling shift in particular—a shift that the label executives themselves were no doubt complicit in creating. They noted that it had become near-impossible to “break” new stars. The sources explained that they could successfully sign loads of new talent and even create digital-era hits that generate millions—if not billions—of streams. The bigger challenge, though, was to find young artists who could break through the noise of the Internet and create the sort of genuine, lasting fandom that turns them into household names and sells out arenas. “Each person I talk to in the industry is more depressed than the person I talked to before them,” one manager said. Given the nature of streaming, and of the TikTok algorithm in particular, the music business has never seemed more gameable—but the ability to create ;a viral smash on TikTok; has also, perversely, led to an oversaturated landscape in which everything feels especially fleeting.

;

;One rare exception to this dispiriting paradigm shift is the twenty-year-old former Disney star and vocal powerhouse Olivia Rodrigo. Rodrigo became a bona-fide pandemic-era success with her début single “Drivers License,” from 2021, a piano power ballad that is both sweeping and finger-snappy, a post-breakup rumination rendered with unusual clarity. It's a song that deeply satisfies the core requirement of great pop music—and pop music's youthful fans—which is to make the mundane feel cinematic: “Yeah, today I drove through the suburbs / And pictured I was driving home to you,” Rodrigo sings.

;

;The song quickly broke streaming records, clocking the single highest number of streams during a single day (holiday music excluded) on Spotify. Rodrigo followed up “Drivers License” with two more hit singles, and then a début album called “;Sour;,” released in the spring of 2021. “Sour” landed at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart and established Rodrigo as one of the finest purveyors of breakup songs in the modern era. (It also won her three Grammys.) Bolstered by her musical-theatre expressiveness, a dynamic soprano, and a sharp lyrical specificity, the eighteen-year-old became not a vanishing sensation but an emotional firebrand and a new generational avatar. She was seemingly anointed to lead the post-;Lorde; and post-;Billie Eilish; wave of alternative-leaning female pop stars. Today, with hindsight, in such an evidently desperate moment for radio pop, “Sour” is being viewed not merely as a breakout star's début but as perhaps the final successful star-making endeavor in pop history.

;
;
;

;And so Rodrigo's new record, “Guts,” is loaded not only with the customary sophomore-album expectations but with ideas about the health of an entire industry. The young star, now twenty, has spoken about being paralyzed by these expectations, and feeling frozen as she sat down to write songs. But “Guts,” the new record, does not betray any of that trepidation. If “Sour” was a single-minded project designed to publicly nurse the specific wound from one romantic betrayal, “Guts” is a transitional record on which Rodrigo begins to turn the mirror away from her exes and playfully, brashly toward herself. Rodrigo is at her best, perhaps owing to her acting background, when delivering screeds in a kind of hyper-self-aware, spoken-word register. “Yes, I know that he's my ex, / But can't two people reconnect?” she poses with an almost audible wink on “Bad Idea Right?” a song on which she contemplates the self-destruction of rekindling an old romance. “I only see him as a friend / The biggest lie I ever said,” she adds, always shrewdly one step ahead of herself.

;

;Novelty is a critical aspect of any pop sensation's rise. Part of what made Rodrigo feel fresh was that she was more indebted to various strains of rock music from the late nineties and two-thousands than to the hip-hop influences that had, for many years, become so enmeshed in the pop universe. Rodrigo cites the White Stripes' ;Jack White; as one of her biggest inspirations, and her music is a canny fusion of piano balladry and retro pop-punk, layered with flavors of grunge and emo. It's a careful selection of styles that work harmoniously with the attitudinal thrust of her music, which sways between cheeky defiance and melodramatic longing. So much of her music sounds like the soundtrack to an early-two-thousands teen drama, each line delivered with an eye roll. And while her music, stylistically, is inherently nostalgic, Rodrigo is a quintessentially modern star in other ways. If pop stars of previous eras attempted to perform sexual maturity beyond their ages, Rodrigo is constantly offering reminders of her adolescent status—or, at least, the idea of adolescence—and revelling in juvenile poses. Lest anyone suspect that she has moved beyond normalcy, she paints a lucid image of bumbling teen-aged relatability: “I laughed at the wrong time, sat with the wrong guy,” she sings on “Ballad of a Homeschooled Girl.” “Searching 'how to start a conversation' on a web site.”

;

;In the early days of her success, Rodrigo confessed to being the “biggest Swiftie in the world.” She had already indicated as much in April of 2020 when she recorded an impassioned, stripped-down piano cover of ;Taylor Swift;'s song “Cruel Summer.” Later, Rodrigo acknowledged that “Cruel Summer” had such an influence on her own single “Deja Vu” that Swift would be added to its credits as a co-writer. Swift's influence can certainly be heard throughout Rodrigo's work, particularly when she sings—as she almost always does—about romantic betrayal. Rodrigo, like Swift, has mastered the narrative art of dressing down her past loves while rendering herself equal parts victim and victor: “I wanna kiss his face with an uppercut,” she sings on “Get Him Back!,” the lively pop-rock centerpiece of “Guts,” a song with the sweet pep of Toni Basil's “Mickey” layered with a menacing, vengeful glower. “I wanna meet his mom / Just to tell her her son sucks,” Rodrigo utters, more spewing than singing.

;

;These days, Rodridgo's Swift worship has been complicated by professional rivalry, at least in the imagination of her listeners. (One major indicator that an artist has achieved a certain status is when rabid fans begin eagerly reading the tea leaves of their lyrics and concocting tales about them.) When Swift sang, quite piercingly on “Anti-Hero,” that, “Sometimes I feel like everybody is a sexy baby / And I'm a monster on a hill,” some assumed she was taking aim at Rodrigo. With “Guts,” fans have feverishly speculated that a song called “The Grudge” was written with Swift in mind: “You have everything and you still want more,” Rodrigo sings on the bridge. Whether or not Swift is the target of the song, “The Grudge” is still, in one way, about Swift—Rodrigo has taken serious cues from Swift about cleverly infusing her music with cryptic tidbits designed to rouse gossip. It's a form of sacred cultural knowledge, being passed from one generation's biggest star to the next. ♦

;“Gets pretty exhausting after a while,” Ah Sahm (Andrew Koji) tells his lover Ah Toy (Olivia Cheng) in the latest season of “Warrior,” on Max. “Surviving?” she asks.

;

;“Being hated,” he replies.

;

;It is the late eighteen-hundreds, a period wedged in between the end of the American Civil War and the signing of ;the Chinese Exclusion Act;. Immigration is high, and racism is rampant. Ah Sahm and Ah Toy are strolling through San Francisco's Chinatown, the only place where they can exist without trouble. This haven, along with most of San Francisco, would eventually be destroyed by the great earthquake of 1906. White architects would be hired to turn the ravaged area into a tourist destination, which is to say, an exotic fantasy—American-style buildings embellished with colorful pagodas, dragon motifs, and other elements of chinoiserie. It is in the original Chinatown, where hope and devastation are twofold, that the television series, based on the writings of ;Bruce Lee;, takes place.

;

;For decades, Lee's TV show, originally called “The Warrior,” was essentially an urban legend. Lee wrote the initial scripts in the late sixties, and the series was teased on “The Pierre Berton Show” in 1971, but it didn't materialize before Lee's death in 1973. In 2007, the director Justin Lin, best known at the time for his Asian American coming-of-age film “Better Luck Tomorrow,” made a mockumentary called “Finishing the Game,” about another unfinished Lee project: “Game of Death,” the movie that Lee was working on when he died. A few years later, Lin, who had become steeped in Bruce Lee lore, contacted Lee's daughter, Shannon, and asked if she still had her father's pitch materials for “The Warrior.” She gave Lin a binder, which included Lee's original eight-page show proposal, along with a half-dozen drafts of sample episodes and scenes. Together, Lin and Shannon Lee, along with Jonathan Tropper, the creator of “Banshee,” expanded these materials into “Warrior,” which premièred in 2019, and recently concluded its third season.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;At the start of the series, Ah Sahm, the show's protagonist, is standing in an immigration line, having just arrived from China. A fellow-migrant is getting pushed around by a trio of white immigration officers, and Ah Sahm jumps to protect him. An officer slaps Ah Sahm, who turns his head slowly and says, “I wouldn't do that again if I were you.” The fighting that follows is brutal and fast, belied by a funky bass that makes the protagonist's steps feel rhythmic. Even those who watch “Warrior” without knowing the series' relation to Bruce Lee will notice that Ah Sahm moves like him. Kung-fu characters are heroic, suspended in the disbelief of a (sometimes cheesy) epic; they're the Greek mythology of East Asia. But if the hero has a believable swagger, as Ah Sahm does, one's mind instantly darts to Lee. During the fight, I half expected Ah Sahm to let out a shriek—an imitation of Lee's infamous battle cry, which defined the actor's singular presence in pop culture. Its use became commensurately racist for the generations of Asian Americans that followed: growing up, I only knew Lee as the minstrel performed at me. But Ah Sahm, who is played by a mixed-race British Japanese actor, is unmistakably modern, with his bravado manifesting in the smooth insults of a proficient English speaker. (“I didn't travel halfway across the world in that damn boat just to amuse a few fat white fucks,” he tells the officers.) The brawl, which Ah Sahm wins handily, is the kind of thing that a nonwhite person fantasizes about after being treated as subhuman—a kick-ass solution to a miasmic attack. Other television series have played on a similar impulse: in “;Watchmen;,” also on Max, a Black cop narrowly escapes a lynching but leaves the noose around his neck, as a form of battle garb, before stomping on a gathering of unhooded Klansmen.

;

;Shortly after his run-in with the immigration officers, Ah Sahm is picked up by a fixer named Wang Chao (Hoon Lee), who brings him to a crime family known as the Hop Wei. Wang, the only character who maintains his Qing dynasty queue, speaks Cantonese. But, during Wang's introduction of Ah Sahm to the Hop Wei, the show uses a camera trick that Tropper refers to as “ ';The Hunt for Red October' transition;.” The camera pans around Wang, and his speech suddenly changes from subtitled Cantonese to fluent American English, turning the audience into native speakers of his language. The camera trick serves as a kind of racist-vibes jammer—preventing viewers from otherizing Wang.

;
;
;

;But there's a cost to translation. The series nods to the Chinglish patois spoken in Chinatown, where words that have hard stops are pronounced instead with tones held as connective filler, the tenors of which can be expressions on their own. The “Ah” (;阿;) in Ah Sahm is a word in Cantonese that, depending on the speaker's lilt, can sound like “Yo Sahm” or “Heyyy Sahm,” a familiar but non-gendered Sahm. And yet the complexity of Cantonese as a developed system of communicating familiarity (and of communicating insults) is lost by making the show so English-forward. “Warrior” compensates for this by infusing the dialogue with wit and attitude, which is perhaps the essence of Cantonese, and the essence of Bruce Lee himself.

;

;“Warrior” tells the story of two crime families—the Hop Wei, which Ah Sahm ultimately joins, and the Long Zii—who are embroiled in a conflict that's known as the Tong Wars. Lin has said that he was eager to develop a relegated history while also making mainstream entertainment. “I've always felt like it's such an American story, but never told,” he explained, in a ;2019 interview;. “Warrior” expands our ideas of what constitutes “American history” by partly focussing on another competition—between the Irish and Chinese communities in San Francisco. The Irish community is led by Dylan Leary (Dean Jagger), a de-facto labor organizer who goes to extreme lengths to maim Chinese workers in sought-after jobs, negotiating with American robber barons and elected officials. Meanwhile, the Long Zii make a deal with a nativist deputy mayor, in exchange for opium and increased policing of the Hop Wei. The deputy, who aspires to become the next mayor of San Francisco, encourages disorder in Chinatown so that he can run on a platform that involves ejecting all Chinese residents from the city. But he's also interested in something more systematic: the creation of legislation to restrict immigration by targeting one specific ethnic group. Leary and the Long Zii both represent marginalized groups that have sold out for marginal power. It's a clear charter to respective destruction, for the Long Zii especially, since their turf war will inevitably end with an immigration ban that will last more than sixty years, followed by another twenty-plus years of restrictions.

;

;At times, “Warrior” can feel radical. It not only conjures figures who have rarely been centered on television before but also supplies these characters with rich inner lives. Still, there's an occasional narrowness, which might be attributed to the fact that the show was conceived in the nineteen-sixties, by an actor who was predominantly interested in documenting the Chinese experience in America. There are barely any Black characters present, aside from a drug dealer and a vixen bartender, and their story lines are bland, despite occurring in the period immediately following Reconstruction. Even if the show's focus is on Irish immigrants and Chinese people making a deal with whitey to tear one another down, it seems like there's still an opportunity to shift the camera to nearby ;Stone Street;, which was once the only Black enclave in San Francisco.

;
;
;

;It might feel nitpicky to criticize an Asian American show for overlooking the strife of other racial groups, but the absence is noticeable in an ambitious period piece that aims to depict America's forgotten histories, as well as the scourge of white supremacy. And it's especially noticeable in 2023, when the narrow focus of “Warrior” feels not unlike the politics of Asian parents whose calls for racial equality have helped bring about ;the end of affirmative action;. Siloing history has an unintended effect of tiering suffering. It also allows groups, driven by their own ethnocentric proclivities, to roll back the progress that others have made.

;

;When the three creators of “Warrior” sought to revive Lee's project, they focussed on shifting the proposal away from the adventure-of-the-week format that was popular in Lee's time and creating something more cinematic and prestige TV-like—the kind of thing that would feel at home on HBO. But, by leaving the rest intact, they inherited the blindspots of the classic kung-fu films to which “Warrior” is a loving tribute. Take, for example, the nineties film franchise “Once Upon a Time in China,” which starred Jet Li as a fictionalized Wong Fei-hung, a physician and fighter who defends the Chinese way of life in an ailing Qing dynasty from warlords. Or the “Ip Man” franchise, which follows the story of Bruce Lee's martial-arts instructor as he fights Japanese occupiers in Foshan during the Second World War, before his forced migration to Hong Kong. Both follow the standard format of kung-fu flicks, by supplying the hero with increasingly challenging opponents whom he must defeat. Each opponent has an advantage over the hero by being bigger and stronger or armed with a unique weapon. But the underdog hero prevails by being smart and remaining composed. These movies, kung-fu westerns, are loosely based around the imperialist scramble to carve up China, and yet it doesn't really matter what external or systemic factors are leading to societal disarray, as those mostly serve as a backdrop. The only thing that matters is the protagonist's journey of overcoming his personal challenges. It's an innocuous if not classic story, but what does prolonged exposure to fictionalized history—or a speculative reality—amount to?

;I'll call it kung-fu politics—a one-sided, regressive vision of the world, developed from action movies. Perhaps the best example is the actor Jackie Chan, who moved the dial in the genre from Qing dynasty kung-fu masters to hero cops. Chan, who won audience's hearts by playing a goofy and delightful protagonist, would eventually come to represent a singular force for good, both onscreen and in real life. But play the hero police officer too often, and it's easy to drift into authoritarian thinking. Over the years, Chan has made comments about how “we Chinese need to be controlled,” or else “we'll just do what we want.” Chan, along with Donnie Yen—the star of a revamped “Ip Man” film franchise—have opposed ;the pro-democracy protests; in Hong Kong, with Chan signing a petition in support of the draconian Chinese security law that was passed to quash the dissent, and Yen calling the dissenters rioters.

;

;“Warrior” wishes to evolve the kung-fu genre, rather than challenge it outright. This is partly done through the show's fight scenes. In an interview several years ago, Ip Chun, the son of Ip Man, who is in his late nineties and has taken over as grand master for his father, spoke about the inevitability of martial arts moving away from Wing Chun, the style of fighting that his father helped Bruce Lee master. “My thought is that the future society that necessitates the need for violence to resolve an issue will be less and less,” he said. “Someone who emphasizes Wing Chun and relies on it for fighting—like one person fighting nine,” he added, “Well, I say it's of no help solving society's problems.” For him, Wing Chun is mostly a “health regimen”—a historically and symbolically rich version of Zumba.

;

;In “Warrior,” martial arts is more than just a health regimen. (Bruce Lee himself, understanding the fantastical nature of action stories, said in 1971 that his show would have to be set in the West: “How else can you justify all this punching and kicking and violence?”) Ah Sahm, in his battles with the Long Zii, often fights alongside the Hop Wei prince, played by Jason Tobin, another mixed-race Chinese British actor, who was born in Hong Kong. Tobin's character—which is not unlike his character in “Better Luck Tomorrow”—might be best described as “stabby.” He is a stereotype of a kind of pent-up Chinese American aggression. Ah Sahm's fighting is more thoughtful, elegant, and deliberate. He is a master of Wing Chun, but, as the series goes on, he transitions to Jeet Kune Do, a more efficient and flexible form of mixed martial arts, invented by Lee. (It has been said that the style is the forerunner to the mixed martial arts that is used by today's UFC fighters.) His movements, a cadence of pulses through his upper torso, with bounces in his shoulders matched by misdirection from his arms and feet, can be reminiscent of a b-boy toprock, a callback to an origin of hip-hop dance.

;

;In both fighting and dance, the body is the main vehicle of expression—ideas, emotions, and history are sublimated into movements that can be explosively deliberate or tranquil. Tropper has talked about how “Warrior” relies on its battle scenes for character development. “I get very into the weeds on the fights, as expressions of the characters and as expressions of what the story is,” he said, in an interview. “Every fight has to tell a story. It can't just be two guys duking it out.”

;
;
;

;“Warrior” likes to switch between elevating action—using it as a way to express key themes—and explicitly nodding to the pulpy seduction of kung fu. It's a continuation of Bruce Lee's work: the actor was known for balancing heady ideas while still entertaining audiences with his sheer physicality. But it's a delicate balance, and, as the show progresses, it becomes harder for the characters to slip their warrior personas on and off. In the third season, a woman encounters Ah Sahm and sees him not as he sees himself—a benevolent outcast finding his path—but as the Hop Wei gangster he publicly presents as. He is practicing shirtless with nunchucks (another Bruce Lee tableau), and the woman sarcastically plays down his prowess. At the end of the scene, she leaves, blushing. Ah Sahm, a little confused, continues training. ♦
